description.p: LAYING VESSEL FOR LAYING PIPELINES ON THE BED OF A BODY OF WATER, AND LAYING VESSEL OPERATING METHOD
TECHNICAL FIELD
The present invention relates to a laying vessel for laying pipelines on the bed of a body of water.

More specifically, the present invention relates to a laying vessel comprising a floating structure; a laying tower hinged to the floating structure and designed to assemble and lay a pipeline on the bed of the body of water; and an A&R system for abandoning and recovering the pipeline; and wherein the A&R system comprises a haul line; and a sheave assembly for guiding the haul line at the laying tower.
BACKGROUND ART

Laying vessels of the above type are described in WO 2009/082191 Al, WO 2009/145607 Al, and WO 01/07812 Al . As is known, A&R systems are used when laying work is interrupted by bad weather, and the pipeline being laid has to be abandoned on the bed of the body of water and recovered later, to continue laying work, when the weather improves. Laying vessels also have to be designed to cope with emergency situations - especially sudden changes in weather - so as to switch rapidly from laying mode to pipeline abandon mode.
To switch as fast as possible from laying to abandon mode, the A&R system is normally fitted directly to the laying tower, as shown in WO 2009/145607 Al and WO 01/07812 Al, or inside the laying tower, as shown in WO 2009/082191 Al .

Known technical solutions often have the drawback of impeding access to the laying tower, and not always allowing easy positioning of the haul line on the sheave assembly. In this connection, it is important to bear in mind that the haul line is defined by at least one rope of considerable size and weight per unit length, and which can only be manoeuvred using special cranes.
DISCLOSURE OF INVENTION
It is an object of the present invention to provide a laying vessel featuring an A&R system that can be activated rapidly, and which, at the same time, does not obstruct laying work.

According to the present invention, there is provided a laying vessel for laying pipelines on the bed of a body of water, the laying vessel comprising a floating structure; a laying tower hinged to the floating structure about a first axis of rotation and designed to assemble and lay a pipeline on the bed of the body of water; and an A&R system for abandoning and recovering the pipeline; and wherein the A&R system
comprises a haul line; and a sheave assembly for guiding the haul line, and which is fitted to the floating structure to move between a work position at the laying tower, and a rest position away from the laying tower.

According to the present invention, the sheave assembly is fitted directly to the floating structure, and is movable between a work position at the laying tower, and a rest position where it can be set up before being moved into the work position where crane operation or even crew work is more difficult. More specifically, the haul line can be secured beforehand to the sheave assembly in the rest position, and later drawn into the work position together with the sheave assembly.

In one embodiment of the invention, the laying tower has a gantry structure, and defines a laying line between two elongated members of the gantry structure; and the sheave assembly is advantageously insertable at least partly between the two elongated members, and close to the laying line, in the work position.
The sheave assembly is preferably movable along a plane beneath, and in a direction perpendicular to, the first axis of rotation.

The first configuration provides for a more spacious layout on the vessel, and the second configuration for improving movement of the sheave
assembly.

In a preferred embodiment, the laying tower comprises at least two gripping assemblies, at least one of which is movable with respect to the other; and the sheave assembly is movable along a plane between the two gripping assemblies.
The sheave assembly can thus be set to the work position while the bottom gripping assembly supports the pipeline .
The sheave assembly preferably comprises a sledge; and a first and second sheave mounted to rotate about a second axis of rotation parallel to the first axis of rotation.
The first and second sheave are preferably located on opposite sides of the laying line.
The first and second sheave can thus be positioned substantially tangent to a plane through the laying line .

In a preferred embodiment, the A&R system comprises a first and second winch; a first and second rope operated by the first and second winch respectively; and a connecting device for connecting the ends of the first and second rope to form the haul line.

So designed, the haul line halves the load on the rope section.
In a preferred embodiment of the invention, the A&R system comprises an elongated auxiliary tool designed to be retained by the laying tower along the laying line, and to be connected to the pipeline. That is, the end portion of the pipeline still inside the laying tower is connected to an auxiliary tool for assisting the A&R procedure, in particular by comprising a dummy string which is gripped by the laying tower; a sledge gripped by the laying tower; and a third sheave which rotates about a third axis of rotation with respect to the sledge to guide the haul line.

The auxiliary tool also has the advantage of comprising a messenger line, which is first wound about the third sheave. The messenger line can be connected to the first rope and wound to draw the end of the first rope up to the end of the second rope, to join the first and second rope, so the resulting haul line extends about the first, second and third sheave and is actually connected indirectly to the pipeline.

When laying the pipeline, the auxiliary tool is set to a rest position, at a distance from the laying tower, to avoid interfering with the laying work. The auxiliary tool is preferably mounted on a locating device designed to support it and to position it on and remove it from the laying tower. More specifically, the locating device
is fitted movably to the floating structure, is insertable at least partly inside the laying tower, and is movable in a given direction along the floating structure.

More specifically, the locating device comprises a first frame mounted to move along the floating structure; and a support, which tilts about a fourth axis of rotation parallel to the first axis of rotation, and is designed to house the auxiliary tool.
So designed, the auxiliary tool can be inserted inside the laying tower in a direction parallel to the laying line.
The locating device also comprises a second frame fitted movably to the first frame; and the tiltable support is fitted to the second frame.
This enables precise positioning of the auxiliary tool with respect to the laying tower.
The present invention also relates to a laying vessel operating method, in particular for converting the laying vessel from a laying configuration to an A&R configuration and vice versa.

According to the present invention, there is provided a method of operating a laying vessel, the laying vessel comprising a floating structure; a laying tower hinged to the floating structure about a first
axis of rotation and designed to assemble and lay a pipeline on the bed of the body of water; and an A&R system for abandoning and recovering the pipeline; and wherein the A&R system comprises a haul line; and a sheave assembly for guiding the haul line; the method comprising the step of selectively running the sheave assembly along the floating structure, between a work position at the laying tower, and a rest position away from the laying tower.
The sheave assembly can thus be moved rapidly between a work position, in which it is used in the A&R procedure, and a rest position, in which it does not interfere with laying work.
In a preferred embodiment of the invention, the method comprises the step of connecting . the haul line to the sheave assembly before moving the sheave assembly into the work position.
The present invention also relates to a method of setting a pipeline laying vessel to a pipeline abandon mode .
According to the present invention, there is provided a method of setting a pipeline laying vessel to a pipeline abandon mode, the method comprising the steps of :

- connecting two ropes, designed to form a haul
line, to a sheave assembly;
- inserting an auxiliary tool, comprising a sheave, inside a laying tower hinged to the laying vessel;
- connecting the auxiliary tool to the pipeline;
- positioning the sheave beneath the travelling plane of the sheave assembly;
- moving the sheave assembly along the travelling plane from a rest position to a work position, in which the sheave assembly is located at least partly inside the laying tower;
- looping at least one of the two ropes about the sheave assembly and the sheave; and
- connecting the ropes.
BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE DRAWINGS
A non-limiting embodiment of the present invention will be described by way of example with reference to the accompanying drawings, in which :
Figure 1 shows a schematic, partly sectioned side view, with parts removed for clarity, of the laying vessel according to the present invention;
Figure 2 shows a partly sectioned rear view, with parts removed for clarity, of a detail of the Figure 1 laying vessel;

Figure 3 shows a larger-scale, partly sectioned side view, with parts removed for clarity, of the Figure
1 vessel with a sheave assembly in the work position;
Figure 4 shows a larger-scale plan view, with parts removed for clarity, of a detail of the Figure 3 sheave assembly;
Figure 5 shows a view in perspective, with parts removed for clarity, of an auxiliary tool of the Figure 1 laying vessel;
Figures 6 and 7 show schematic side views, with parts removed for clarity, of the laying vessel at respective pipeline abandon configuration stages;
Figure 8 shows a larger-scale view in perspective, with parts removed for clarity, of a pipeline abandon configuration stage;
Figures 9-14 show side views, with parts removed for clarity, of respective A&R configuration stages;
Figure 15 shows a plan view, with parts removed for clarity, of an A&R configuration stage.
BEST MODE FOR CARRYING OUT THE INVENTION
Number 1 in Figure 1 indicates as a whole a laying vessel for laying a pipeline 2 on the bed (not shown) of a body of water 3.

Laying vessel 1 comprises a floating structure 4; a J-type laying tower 5; and an A&R system 6. Floating structure 4 comprises a hull 7; a weather deck 8; a stern 9; and a bow not shown in the drawings.
In the example shown, laying tower 5 is mounted at stern 9, and is hinged to rotate selectively about an axis of rotation Al into a plurality of substantially vertical work positions, and a substantially horizontal rest position (not shown in the drawings) .
In one variation not shown, the laying tower is mounted at the bow, and, in another variation not shown, is mounted on a platform along a bulwark of the floating structure .

Laying tower 5 defines a laying line 10, and has a top portion 11 equipped with devices (not shown) for assembling pipes (not shown) into pipeline 2 as pipeline 2 is laid; a centre portion 12 equipped with a top gripping assembly 131 and bottom gripping assembly 132 for gripping pipeline 2; and a bottom portion 14 comprising a laying ramp 15. At least one of gripping assemblies 131, 132 is movable parallel to laying line 10 to feed pipeline 2 along laying tower 5 by gripping assemblies 131 and 132 gripping the pipeline alternately. The bottom gripping assembly 132 is hinged to and tilts with respect to laying tower 5 into a withdrawn position (shown by the dash line in Figure 1) from laying line 10, to permit insertion of bulky equipment along laying tower 5. And floating structure 4 comprises two parallel arms 16 (only one shown in Figure
1) which extend over weather deck 8 and support laying tower 5 in rotary manner, so the axis of rotation Al of laying tower 5 is located over weather deck 8, at the ends of arms 16.

As shown in Figure 2, laying tower 5 is located between arms 16, and comprises a gantry structure comprising two parallel elongated lateral members 17, which, at the bottom ends, support laying ramp 15 defined, in the example shown, by a lattice structure. Elongated members 17 are connected by cross members (not shown) , are hinged to arms 16 about axis of rotation Al, and define a gap in which laying line 10 extends.

As shown in Figure 1, A&R system 6 comprises a sheave assembly 18; an auxiliary tool 19; a locating device 20 for positioning auxiliary tool 19; and two winches 21, 22 comprising respective ropes 23, 24, which are eventually joined to form a haul line 23, 24. In actual use, sheave assembly 18 serves to guide haul line 23, 24 at laying tower 5.

Sheave assembly 18 is fitted to floating structure 4 to move between a rest position (Figure 1) and a work position (Figure 3) , is located at stern 9, is fitted to move with respect to floating structure 4 along a plane beneath weather deck 8, is connected to an actuator (not shown in the drawings), and is movable in a direction Dl
parallel to weather deck 8 and perpendicular to axis of rotation Al .
As shown more clearly in Figure 3, sheave assembly 18 comprises a sledge 26 fitted movably to floating structure 4.

As shown in Figure 4, sheave assembly 18 comprises two sheaves 27, 28, which rotate about a common axis of rotation A2 parallel to axis of rotation Al (Figure 3) . Sheaves 27, 28 are fitted to and project from two forks 29, so they are located on opposite sides of laying line 10 in the work position, and do not interfere with pipeline 2 or auxiliary tool 19 (Figure 1), which, in use, may be located along laying line 10. Sheaves 27, 28 may thus be positioned tangent to a plane through laying line 10.

As shown in Figure 3, sheave assembly 18 comprises two fasteners 30, 31 for connecting respective ends of ropes 23, 24 to sheave assembly 18. More specifically, the ends of ropes 23, 24 are defined by respective eyelets 32, 33, and are connectable to each other by means of a connecting device 34, which is fixed to sledge 26 by fastener 31, and is connected to the end of rope 24. The ends of ropes 23, 24 are fastened to sheave assembly 18 in the rest position, so they move with sheave assembly 18 into the work position, as opposed to
using cranes. Sheave assembly 18 also comprises a temporary rope 35 connected at one end to connecting device 34, and at the other end to an anchor 36 fitted to sledge 26.

As shown in Figure 4, sheave assembly 18 comprises a guide 37, which extends along a given arc about axis of rotation A2 and on opposite sides of sheave 28 to guide connecting device 34 and temporary rope 35 when releasing and recovering rope 24 from and onto laying vessel 1 (Figure 3) .

As shown in Figure 5, auxiliary tool 19 is an elongated member shown, in the example, aligned with laying line 10, and comprises, working downwards in Figure 5, a dummy string 38; a locking device 39 hinged to dummy string 38; a sledge 40 attached to locking device 39; and a float 41 attached to sledge 40 and which connects to pipeline 2. Auxiliary tool 19 also comprises a sheave 42 fitted to sledge 40 to rotate about an axis of rotation A3; and a messenger line 43 connected at both ends to dummy string 38 and guided by sheave 42. Dummy string 38 is designed to be gripped by gripping assemblies 131 and 132 (Figure 1), and to advance inside laying tower 5 in the same way as pipeline 2; locking device 39 is designed to selectively lock and release sledge 40 to and from dummy string 38;
and sledge 40 is guided along laying tower 5 and immersed in the body of water 3 when abandoning and recovering the pipeline. More specifically, sledge 40 comprises skids 44 designed to engage grooves (not shown) parallel to laying line 10 and formed along elongated members 17 (Figure 2) .

As shown in Figures 6 and 7, locating device 20 comprises a frame 45 movable along weather deck 8 in direction Dl; a frame 46 mounted on frame 45 to move in direction Dl; and a support 47 hinged to frame 46 and for supporting auxiliary tool 19. Locating device 20 is at least partly insertable between elongated members 17 of laying tower 5, to align auxiliary tool 19 with laying line 10 inside the laying tower, as shown in Figure 5. Preferably, frame 45 runs along rails (not shown) on weather deck 8, and frame 46 runs along rails (not shown) on frame 45. Frames 45 and 46 are moved by respective actuators (not shown) , and support 47 is tilted by a further actuator 48 which, in the example shown, is a hydraulic cylinder.
In actual use, switching from pipeline 2 laying mode to pipeline 2 abandon mode comprises :
- connecting ropes 23 and 24 to sheave assembly 18;
- inserting auxiliary tool 19 inside laying tower

5;
- connecting auxiliary tool 19 to pipeline 2;
positioning sledge 40 of auxiliary tool 19 beneath the travelling plane of sheave assembly 18;
- moving sheave assembly 18 into the work position;
- connecting ropes 23 and 24 to form haul line 23, 24, which is guided by sheaves 27, 28 and 42.
To avoid interference between sledge 40 and sheave assembly 18, sheave assembly 18 can only be moved into the work position when sledge 40 of auxiliary tool 19 is located beneath sheave assembly 18.

As shown in Figure 8, ropes 23 and 24 are connected by messenger line 43 wound beforehand about sheave 42. At this stage, pipeline 2 is connected to auxiliary tool 19, in turn supported by top gripping assembly 131 (Figure 1) gripping dummy string 38; and the ends of messenger line 43 are released from dummy string 38 and wound about sheaves 27 and 28.

As shown in Figures 9 and 10, messenger line 43 is connected at one end to the end of rope 23, and at the other end to a service winch 49 (Figure 11) . As shown in Figure 11, service winch 49 takes up messenger line 43 to position the end of rope 23 at connecting device 34 and connect eyelet 32 of rope 23 to connecting device 34 as shown in Figure 12. At this point, haul line 23, 24 is connected, rope 23 is drawn by respective winch 21
(Figure 1), and rope 24 is released from respective winch 22 (Figure 1) to position connecting device 34 along guide 37, as shown in Figure 13. Travel of connecting device 34 along guide 37 is shown in more detail in Figure 15. Ropes 23 and 24 are wound and unwound respectively until connecting device 34 passes sheave 28 (Figure 15) and temporary rope 35 is tensioned (Figure 14) . At which point, temporary rope 35 is detached and recovered, and haul line 23, 24 can be tensioned to support the load of pipeline 2. Once the load of pipeline 2 is transferred to haul line 23, 24, locking device 39 is released from sledge 40, which is lowered into body of water 3 together with pipeline 2.
Before lowering sledge 40 out of laying tower 5, bottom gripping assembly 132 (Figure 1) is tilted away from laying line 10 to avoid interfering with sledge 40.

The advantages of the present invention substantially consist in converting the laying vessel rapidly from laying mode to A&R mode; and in not obstructing laying work, by virtue of the A&R system as a whole being substantially located at a distance from the laying tower.
Clearly, changes may be made to the embodiment of the invention described without, however, departing from the scope of the accompanying Claims.

claim.claim-text: CLAIMS

1) A laying vessel for laying pipelines on the bed of a body of water, the laying vessel (1) comprising a floating structure (4); a laying tower (5) hinged to the floating structure (4) about a first axis of rotation (Al) and designed to assemble and lay a pipeline (2) on the bed of the body of water (3); and an A&R system (6) for abandoning and recovering the pipeline (2); and wherein the A&R system (6) comprises a haul line (23, 24); and a sheave assembly (18) for guiding the haul line (23, 24), and which is fitted to the floating structure (4) to move between a work position at the laying tower (5) , and a rest position away from the laying tower (5).

2) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 1, wherein the laying tower (5) comprises two elongated members (17), and defines a laying line (10) between the two elongated members (17); the sheave assembly (18) being insertable at least partly between the two elongated members (17) and close to the laying line (10) in the work position.
3) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 1 or 2, wherein the sheave assembly (18) is movable along a plane beneath the first axis of rotation (Al).

4) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of the
foregoing Claims, wherein the sheave assembly (18) is movable in a direction (Dl) perpendicular to the first axis of rotation (Al) .

5) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of the foregoing Claims, wherein the laying tower (5) comprises at least two gripping assemblies (131, 132), at least one of which is movable with respect to the other; the sheave assembly (18) being movable along a plane between the two gripping assemblies (131, 132) .

6) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of the foregoing Claims, wherein the floating structure (4) comprises two parallel arms (16); the laying tower (5) being hinged to the free ends of the arms (16) .
7) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of the foregoing Claims, wherein the sheave assembly (18) comprises a sledge (26) ; and a first and second sheave
(27, 28) mounted to rotate about a second axis of rotation (A2) parallel to the first axis of rotation
(Al) .
8) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 7, wherein the first and second sheave (27, 28) are located on opposite sides of the laying line (10).

9) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 7 or 8, wherein the A&R system (6) comprises a first and second winch (21, 22); a first and second rope (23, 24)
operated by the first and second winch (21, 22) respectively; and a connecting device (34) for connecting the ends of the first and second rope (23, 24) to form the haul line (23, 24).

10) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of the foregoing Claims, wherein the A&R system (6) comprises an elongated auxiliary tool (19) designed to be retained by the laying tower (5) along the laying line (10), and to be connected to the pipeline (2).

11) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 10, wherein the auxiliary tool (19) comprises a dummy string (38) which is gripped by the laying tower (5) ; a sledge (40) guided by the laying tower (5); and a third sheave (42) which rotates about a third axis of rotation (A3) with respect to the sledge (40) to guide the haul line (23, 24) .
12) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 11, wherein the auxiliary tool (19) comprises a messenger line (43) wound about the third sheave (42) .

13) A laying vessel as claimed in any one of Claims 10 to 12, and comprising a locating device (20) fitted movably to the floating structure (4) and designed to position the auxiliary tool (19) inside the laying tower (5) and extract the auxiliary tool (19) from the laying tower (5) .
14) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 13, wherein the locating device (20) is insertable at least partly inside the laying tower (5) and movable in a given direction (Dl) along the floating structure (4).
15) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 13 or 14, wherein the locating device (20) comprises a first frame
(45) mounted to move along the floating structure (4); and a support (47) which tilts about a fourth axis of rotation (A4) parallel to the first axis of rotation
(Al); the support (47) being designed to house the auxiliary tool (19).

16) A laying vessel as claimed in Claim 15, wherein the locating device (20) comprises a second frame (46) mounted to move along the first frame (45); the tiltable support (47) being fitted to the first frame (45).

sheave assembly (18) along the floating structure (4), between a work position at the laying tower (5), and a rest position away from the laying tower (5) .

19, and comprising the step of moving the sheave assembly (18) along a plane beneath the first axis of rotation (Al ) .

- connecting two ropes (23, 24), designed to form a haul line, to a sheave assembly (18);
- inserting an auxiliary tool (19), comprising a sheave (42) , inside a laying tower (5) hinged to the laying vessel (1) ;
connecting the auxiliary tool (19) to the pipeline ( 2 ) ;
positioning the sheave (42) beneath the travelling plane of the sheave assembly (18);

moving the sheave assembly (18) along the
travelling plane from a rest position to a work position, in which the sheave assembly (18) is located at least partly inside the laying tower (5) ; .
- looping at least one of the two ropes (23, 24) about the sheave assembly (18) and the sheave (42); and
- connecting the ropes (23, 24).
